conclusion: To find the maximum value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) as the equilateral triangle loop enters the uniform magnetic field, we need to consider the rate of change of magnetic flux through the loop.
The induced EMF is given by Faraday's Law of Induction, E = -dΦ/dt.

For a conductor moving in a uniform magnetic field, the induced EMF can also be calculated as E = BLv⊥, where B is the magnetic field strength, L is the length of the conductor perpendicular to both B and v, and v⊥ is the component of velocity perpendicular to the conductor.
In this case, since the velocity v is perpendicular to MN and B is perpendicular to the plane, we can use E = BLv.
The process consists of two main stages: 1. When side DE enters the magnetic field. 2. When side CE enters the magnetic field.
Let the side length of the equilateral triangle be a. The angle of an equilateral triangle is 60°.
As the loop moves to the right, the rightmost part of the loop that is cutting the magnetic field lines is the side DE.
The length of the wire effectively cutting the magnetic field lines increases as the loop moves further into the field.
Let x be the horizontal distance the loop has moved into the magnetic field from the moment D touches MN.
The vertical height of the triangle from C to the base DE is h = a sin 60° = a√3/2.
Consider a point at a horizontal distance x from MN. The segment of the wire cutting the field is part of side DE.
The width of the loop inside the magnetic field, perpendicular to the velocity v, can be found using similar triangles.
As point D enters, the length cutting the flux increases. When point E is about to enter the field, the length of the wire cutting the flux is maximum.
The part of the loop inside the magnetic field has a varying effective length.
Let's consider the segment of the loop currently inside the magnetic field that is perpendicular to the velocity. This is the horizontal length at the leading edge.
When side DE is entering the field, the induced EMF is generated by the segment of DE that is crossing the boundary.
The length of the conductor effectively cutting the field lines is the horizontal segment of the triangle at the leading edge.
The maximum length of this segment occurs just before point E enters the field, when the length is equal to the side length a.
